article:
The 'section sign' (Â§, Unicode U+00A7 , HTML entity
§ ) is a typographical character used mainly to refer to a
particular section of a document, such as a legal code. It is also
called "double S", "sectional symbol", [[wikt:en:signum#Latin|signum]]
[[wikt:en:sectio#Latin|sectiÅnis]].

It is frequently used along with the pilcrow (Â¶), or paragraph sign. When
duplicated, as Â§Â§, it is read as the plural "sections" (Â§Â§ 13–21), much as
"pp." (pages) is the plural of "p." (short for the Latin pagina). The likely
origin of the section sign is the digraph formed by the combination of two S'es
(from the Latin signum sectionis).

Like the dagger (â ) and double dagger (â¡), it is also sometimes used to link to
a footnote where the asterisk (*) is already in use on a given page; however,
these usages are declining in favor of numbered footnotes, usually linked by a
superscripted and/or square bracketed number.
